column4: Hi there, is there a difference between GDM and the X server?
GDM handles the login. its running on top of X.
I want to restart the X server on a remote machine since I edited the xorg.conf.  (Specifically, I need to turn off direct rendering)
so  they are radically different things.
that's also what I thought, thanks.. Do you know how to restart the X server?
'sudo service gdm restart'  should restart X
thanks. :)
service gdm restart seems to have restarted GDM, I don't know if it restarted X.. My problem still remains, it's still doing direct rendering
do you know how to turn off direct rendering?  I'm trying to run a program remotely that opens an OpenGL window
do ' sudo service gdm stop       ' and  X should stop. :)
never noticed or needed to.
I can still open X windows even after "sudo service gdm stop"
Hmm. somthing is odd there.. that should log you out back to the GDm login screen
I'm logging into the machine remotely.  I can't see its desktop
so  err.. what does this have to do with xorg.conf then?
my problem is that the OpenGL windows are rendering on the remote machine, whereas I need them to render on the local machine.  I'm not sure if this can be accomplished by editing xorg.conf
you did 'ssh -X remotebox'  ?
I did "ssh -Y remotebox"
i dont think xorg.conf has any thing to do with that.. I wonder what would happen if  you just shut down gdm, on the remote box. :) then there would be no display fior it to go to.
what program is this anyway>?

when I type in "glxgears -info", the first line is: GL_RENDERER   = Mesa X11.  What I would like it to say is: GL_RENDERER   = GeForce 9500 GT/PCI/SSE2 (the gfx card on my local box .. it isn't on the remote box)
one normally dosent run  programs that use 3d graphics over the network like that.
I know, but for my application, that's what I'd like to do
